Thriller Writer Lee Child Chooses 'Sophie's Choice'

summary-body.p: Lee Child, the best-selling creator of tough guy Jack Reacher, makes a surprising recommendation for the WSJ Book Club.

headline.deck: Lee Child, the best-selling creator of tough-guy Jack Reacher, makes a surprising recommendation for the WSJ Book Club

media.media-credit: Axel Dupeux for The Wall Street Journal

article-body.p: Lee Child is one of the most successful thriller writers of his generation. His 18 Jack Reacher novels have sold nearly 100 million copies in 42 languages and have all been optioned by Hollywood. Mr. Child writes polished, efficient prose that keeps his hero, a highly moral—and lethal—ex-MP, roaming the country, dispensing brutal justice.

highlight.link: Join the WSJ Book Club here.

article-body.p: So it was a surprise that the British author didn't choose a classic thriller for his stint hosting the WSJ Book Club. Instead, he picked William Styron's "Sophie's Choice," which runs almost 600 pages and couldn't be more different from a Reacher novel in style and structure. (In the Journal's book club, authors serve as guest hosts, selecting their favorite books and describing how those works have influenced them. Coming hosts include Margaret Atwood.)

highlight.link: Read the first chapter of "Sophie's Choice."

article-body.p: Styron's epic tale of a Holocaust survivor coming to terms with her horrific past unfolds at languid pace, slowly disclosing key snippets of information. "Sophie's Choice" won the National Book Award in 1980 and Meryl Streep received an Oscar for portraying Sophie in the 1982 film. Styron died in 2006. The book's title has entered the vernacular to mean deciding between two terrible alternatives.

Mr. Child, 59, stumbled upon the novel on a bookstore's remainder table. He has reread it "probably no more than six times" and remains impressed by its scope and structure. He praises Styron's command of suspense and how he takes on "really heavyweight subjects."

"If you look at literary fiction," Mr. Child says, "it's become very slight, very internal and very trivial by comparison. The idea that we could get a big literary novel about substantive issues like World War II, concentration camps or mental illness, seems to me wishful thinking now. I regret that."

Mr. Child, whose 19th Reacher novel, "Personal," comes out Tuesday, seems keen to prop up Styron's reputation. He is revered and taught but "maybe slightly less than he should," Mr. Child says. "In baseball terms, I don't think he's a Hall of Famer but he probably should be."

Over the next six weeks, we'll be reading "Sophie's Choice," with Mr. Child supplying weekly questions and discussion points. You can follow the conversation by visiting WSJ.com/bookclub. You also can ask questions and join in on Facebook and Twitter at #WSJbookclub. In October, we'll have a live video chat with Mr. Child. Below, an edited interview.

p.highlight: We thought you might choose a classic thriller.

article-body.p: When I'm reading for fun or relaxation or for elucidation, it's better for me to stay away from what I can do myself. If it's something I can do myself, it's like watching a DVD with the commentary track turned on. This voice in the back of my head is saying, 'Yeah, I see what you're doing. OK, now you're going to have to do this.' "

It is so layered.... I say, 'If you're only going to read 10 books in your lifetime, make them "Sophie's Choice."' Depending on how you sneak up on it, it's a different novel every time. It's a novel about being a novelist. It's also a Southern novel. It's also obviously a New York novel. It's also a European novel, a World War II novel, and, at its heart, a very elemental suspense novel.

p.highlight: Are there passages you recall or love?

article-body.p: There are many passages that I love, I would say more for content rather than style. I don't think it's a particularly beautiful or lyrical novel. I think sentence by sentence that you wouldn't say that this is the most beautifully written thing. It's very functional and I don't mean to damn with faint praise at all. He is recounting the way that that guy would have thought and talked at the time.

p.highlight: Writing about sex is always a challenge. Styron does it extremely well. There's a lot of sex but it's never awkward, it's not embarrassing, and it's kind of hot, actually.

article-body.p: It is.

p.highlight: Jack Reacher describes his hot showers more explicitly than his—

article-body.p: I've tried it lots of different ways, offstage, onstage, close-up. It's incredibly difficult. I think the reason is, if you look at what Styron does, he's willing to let Stingo [the narrator] look like a klutz and an idiot. He's willing to set him up as naive and horny. He just so desperately wants to get laid. And I can't really do that, with a modern thriller hero who is supposed to be competent. You can't have him suddenly looking like a horny teenager.

p.highlight: In terms of plot development, this is a classic onion peel, like a striptease to the nth degree.

article-body.p: That is narrative propulsion of the finest sort. And we just keep waiting to find out what it is. And humans just love that, we're hard-wired to get the answer. And so we stick with that narrative for hundreds of pages, driven to find out what is up with her. It's the onion peel that never stops. It's one thing after another.

p.highlight: Here you don't even find out about the existence of a major character until well over halfway through the book.

article-body.p: That is audacious. That is a first-rate novelist walking the high wire.

p.highlight: There are so many wonderful set pieces in here. I think it's the first chapter that describes his job. It's a hilarious piece of writing that stands brilliantly on its own.

article-body.p: It's one set piece after another. Each could stand alone as a short story in the New Yorker.

p.highlight: How did you discover this book?

article-body.p: I discovered it just browsing in a bookstore. I was in New York, and it was in the early days of Barnes & Noble, and back then it seemed revolutionary to me that they sold remainder books. They had a hard copy of the Random House version for $5.98. I was poor back then and I remember: 'F— me! A hardcover book for six bucks?' I was all over that. And I bought it and I read it and it just knocked me out. Since then, I've read all his other stuff, but if I see a good edition of it, I still will buy it, the subliminal joy of replicating the first time.

p.highlight: How many times do you think you've read it?

article-body.p: Not more than probably six times, which is a lot more than I would normally read a book, but not my most ever, because it's not a comfort book. It's still a challenging book because of the length, the density and the blackness of its heart.

p.highlight: As a thriller writer, do you tip your hat to his thriller chops?

article-body.p: I totally do. I think he's rare—a writer of that stature, who completely understands suspense.

p.highlight: What do you think of the movie?

article-body.p: It's a terrific movie. The book has got so much in it. I used to work in television and we very rarely made something completely unabridged. And when we did—my company made "Brideshead Revisited," for instance, and it's actually a slim novel and that took 13 hours. "Sophie's Choice" would be up there between 30, 40 hours, and that is too long for a movie. So it's got to be radically condensed and they did a pretty good job. And it's got two fantastic performances. Meryl Streep is just an actress of the highest possible quality, working to the best of her ability there. And Kevin Kline—talk about underappreciated. I think he's the finest actor of his generation. The story's in safe hands.

p.highlight: Could Jack Reacher have saved Sophie?

article-body.p: In the tradition in which I write, you've got John D. MacDonald's Travis McGee. Travis McGee would have absolutely saved Sophie, by having sex with her, because that was the key to everything for MacDonald. But that's an out-of-date point of view. Then you've got Spenser by Robert Parker. Spenser's girlfriend was a psychiatrist, so between them… Would Reacher have saved Sophie? No, because he doesn't have the skill set.
